articles.headline: More Deaths Are Linked to Device
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration has received from the Guidant Corporation several new reports about recent patient deaths associated with short circuits in company heart devices, agency records show.     The three new cases all occurred after Jun...
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration has received from the Guidant Corporation several new reports about recent patient deaths associated with short circuits in company heart devices, agency records show.     The three new cases all occurred after June when Guidant recalled the heart devices at issue. The recalls took place after the company came under scrutiny for failing to promptly warn doctors and patients about the risks of short circuits. The new reports bring the number of known deaths associated with the flaw to seven.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has received from the Guidant Corporation several new reports about recent patient deaths associated with short circuits in company heart devices, agency records show.

articles.headline: Two Utilities Said to Hold Merger Talks
articles.snippet: The parent of Florida Power and Light is in advanced talks to acquire the Constellation Energy Group for more than $11 billion, according to people briefed on the negotiations. A deal would create a utility behemoth with operations all along the E...
articles.abstract: The parent of Florida Power and Light is in advanced talks to acquire the Constellation Energy Group for more than $11 billion, according to people briefed on the negotiations. A deal would create a utility behemoth with operations all along the East Coast, from Maine to Florida.     The talks come as deal-making in energy has reached feverish heights. Oil and gas deals alone have totaled $180 billion so far this year, the most activity since 1998, according to Thomson Financial.
articles.lead_paragraph: The parent of Florida Power and Light is in advanced talks to acquire the Constellation Energy Group for more than $11 billion, according to people briefed on the negotiations. A deal would create a utility behemoth with operations all along the East Coast, from Maine to Florida.

articles.headline: Bright Spot on Gulf as Casinos Rush to Rebuild
articles.snippet: Anyone visiting this town in the days after Hurricane Katrina might reasonably have concluded that it would be a long while before slot machines were again ringing their incessant chimes. The storm destroyed 9 of 10 floating casinos in Biloxi, and...
articles.abstract: Anyone visiting this town in the days after Hurricane Katrina might reasonably have concluded that it would be a long while before slot machines were again ringing their incessant chimes. The storm destroyed 9 of 10 floating casinos in Biloxi, and the tenth suffered significant damage.      Yet so well financed is the gambling industry -- and so profitable the facilities that line the beaches here -- that one casino is set to open its doors to the public on Dec. 22. Another is to reopen the day after Christmas. A third, the Palace Casino, will have spent $23 million in four months to reopen by New Year's Eve, said the general manager, Keith Crosby.
articles.lead_paragraph: BILOXI, Miss., Dec. 9 - Anyone visiting this town in the days after Hurricane Katrina might reasonably have concluded that it would be a long while before slot machines were again ringing their incessant chimes. The storm destroyed 9 of 10 floating casinos in Biloxi, and the tenth suffered significant damage.

articles.headline: Fed Gives Mixed Sign on Rates
articles.snippet: After raising interest rates for the 13th time in a row on Tuesday, the Federal Reserve said that its work was not yet finished.     As expected, the Fed raised the benchmark federal funds rate on overnight bank loans to 4.25 percent, from 4 perce...
articles.abstract: After raising interest rates for the 13th time in a row on Tuesday, the Federal Reserve said that its work was not yet finished.     As expected, the Fed raised the benchmark federal funds rate on overnight bank loans to 4.25 percent, from 4 percent. At the same time, it dampened the hopes of some on Wall Street that it was near the end of its campaign to control inflation by tightening its monetary policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 - After raising interest rates for the 13th time in a row on Tuesday, the Federal Reserve said that its work was not yet finished.

articles.headline: New Army Rules May Snarl Talks With McCain on Detainee Issue
articles.snippet: The Army has approved a new, classified set of interrogation methods that may complicate negotiations over legislation proposed by Senator John McCain to bar cruel and inhumane treatment of detainees in American custody, military officials said Tu...
articles.abstract: The Army has approved a new, classified set of interrogation methods that may complicate negotiations over legislation proposed by Senator John McCain to bar cruel and inhumane treatment of detainees in American custody, military officials said Tuesday.     The techniques are included in a 10-page classified addendum to a new Army field manual that was forwarded this week to Stephen A. Cambone, the under secretary of defense for intelligence policy, for final approval, they said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 - The Army has approved a new, classified set of interrogation methods that may complicate negotiations over legislation proposed by Senator John McCain to bar cruel and inhumane treatment of detainees in American custody, military officials said Tuesday.

articles.headline: Enron's Chief Offers His Case
articles.snippet: The well known and the powerful often appear before the Houston Forum, one of the city's elite spots for speakers. Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, gave a recent talk, as did Michael Chertoff, the homeland security secretary.      But t...
articles.abstract: The well known and the powerful often appear before the Houston Forum, one of the city's elite spots for speakers. Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, gave a recent talk, as did Michael Chertoff, the homeland security secretary.      But the speaker who stirred up the greatest interest was one of Houston's own: Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman of Enron, who spoke on Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, Dec. 13 - The well known and the powerful often appear before the Houston Forum, one of the city's elite spots for speakers. Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, gave a recent talk, as did Michael Chertoff, the homeland security secretary.

articles.headline: No Sign of Progress on Farm Issue as World Trade Meeting Opens
articles.snippet: With protesters chanting slogans outside, scuffling with police and even jumping into the harbor, the World Trade Organization ministerial conference began here on Tuesday with ministers quickly starting talks on agriculture and assistance to the ...
articles.abstract: With protesters chanting slogans outside, scuffling with police and even jumping into the harbor, the World Trade Organization ministerial conference began here on Tuesday with ministers quickly starting talks on agriculture and assistance to the world's poorest countries.     But while many countries vowed to provide aid and greater export opportunities for poor countries, there was, as expected, little sign of immediate progress on the core goal of lifting global barriers to farm trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Dec. 13 - With protesters chanting slogans outside, scuffling with police and even jumping into the harbor, the World Trade Organization ministerial conference began here on Tuesday with ministers quickly starting talks on agriculture and assistance to the world's poorest countries.

articles.headline: To Halt Abuses, U.S. Will Inspect Jails Run by Iraq
articles.snippet: American military officers will inspect hundreds of detention centers and embed with Iraqi police commando units and other Interior Ministry forces to try to halt widespread abuses uncovered by raids on two Iraqi-run detention centers in Baghdad i...
articles.abstract: American military officers will inspect hundreds of detention centers and embed with Iraqi police commando units and other Interior Ministry forces to try to halt widespread abuses uncovered by raids on two Iraqi-run detention centers in Baghdad in the last month, the American ambassador pledged Tuesday.      The ambassador, Zalmay Khalilzad, said at a news conference that ''over 100'' of the 169 detainees whom American troops found on Nov. 15 in an Interior Ministry bunker in the Jadriya neighborhood had been abused, a far higher figure than the Americans had previously disclosed. In the second raid last week, on another makeshift detention center run by a notorious police commando unit, the Wolf Brigade, as many as 26 of the 625 detainees jammed into the overcrowded center had been abused, Mr. Khalilzad said.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 13 - American military officers will inspect hundreds of detention centers and embed with Iraqi police commando units and other Interior Ministry forces to try to halt widespread abuses uncovered by raids on two Iraqi-run detention centers in Baghdad in the last month, the American ambassador pledged Tuesday.

articles.headline: Sunni Bastion Now Turning to Ballot Box
articles.snippet: Along the main boulevard here in Saddam Hussein's hometown, hundreds of campaign posters have flowered where insurgents once tossed homemade bombs at American troops.     The guerrilla war found fertile ground in Tikrit, and defiant Sunni Arabs bo...
articles.abstract: Along the main boulevard here in Saddam Hussein's hometown, hundreds of campaign posters have flowered where insurgents once tossed homemade bombs at American troops.     The guerrilla war found fertile ground in Tikrit, and defiant Sunni Arabs boycotted the elections in January.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIKRIT, Iraq, Dec. 13 - Along the main boulevard here in Saddam Hussein's hometown, hundreds of campaign posters have flowered where insurgents once tossed homemade bombs at American troops.
